====Googlehits===
  +
The term "googlehits" refers to the number of hits reported by Google for any given search criteria. It's long been used as a measure of the relevancy of the search term(s), but controversy has surrouded this approach, namely with respect to the long-running controversy between what's currently relevant, which might incite a high number of Googlehits, and what's relevant to the long-term interests of any given culture. For example, as of this writing, the term "Constitution" racked up 148,000,000 Google hits, while the term "USA" racked up 1,750,000,000 Google hits. Since the term Constitution applies to many countries, who's to say the term "USA" is necessarily more important, or more relavent, even though it garnered nearly 12x the number of Google hits as "Constitution." Put simply, popularity does not translate into relevancy, and should not be used as a measure of the worth of any content, on any forum. Googlehits are simply a measure of public interest, nothing more. The Mona Lisa received just 13,300,000 Google hits, twelve times less than "Constitution," and more than 150 times less than "USA." Some would conclude that it's lack of Googlehits renders it irrelevant. By comparison, "insomnia" racked up 22,100,000 hits, which is nearly double. Another example: The term "Jvari," which describes a Georgian Orthodox monestary of the 6th century near Mkskheta, rendered just 23,100 Googlehits, a mere 1 of 75,000 the hits that USA ranked. Yet is it relevant? Certainly, and for many reasons, including cultural, historical, geographical, political, etc. The botton line is that using Googlehits to judge the worth of the relevancy of any topic is faulty from the beginning, as it relies on the premise that popularity is equivalent to relevance, significance, or notability, when in fact, popularity is often contrary to one or more of these far more important criteria for inclusion into any compilation of knowledge.
